revision.text:
{{distinguish|Intelpedia}} {{external links|date=September 2016}} [[File:Intellipedia Logo.jpg|thumb|Intellipedia Logo]] [[File:Screenshot-Intellipedia.png|thumb|A screenshot of the Intellipedia interface]] [[File:Three_wikis_that_make_up_Intellipedia2.jpg|thumb|The three wikis that make up Intellipedia.]] '''Intellipedia''' is an online system for collaborative data sharing used by the [[United States intelligence community|United States Intelligence Community]] (IC).http://www.intelink.gov {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225104427/http://www.intelink.gov/ |date=2012-02-25 }} It was established as a pilot project in late 2005 and formally announced in April 2006.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/news-information/featured-story-archive/2008-featured-story-archive/intellipedia-marks-second-anniversary.html |title=Intellipedia marks second anniversary |publisher=CIA Press Release |date=March 20, 2008}}INSA, Analytic Transformation, September 2007, p. 12. Intellipedia consists of three [[wiki]]s running on the separate [[Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System|JWICS]] (Intellipedia-TS), [[SIPRNet]] (Intellipedia-S), and [[DNI-U]] (Intellipedia-U) [[Computer network|networks]]. The [[Classified information|levels of classification]] allowed for information on the three wikis are [[Top Secret]] [[Sensitive Compartmented Information]] (TS SCI), [[Classified information in the United States#Secret|Secret]] (S), and [[Sensitive But Unclassified]] (SBU or [[For Official Use Only|FOUO]]) information, respectively. Each of the wikis is used by individuals with appropriate [[Security clearance|clearances]] from the 16 agencies of the [[US intelligence community]] and other national-security related organizations, including [[Unified Combatant Command|Combatant Commands]] and other federal departments. The wikis are not open to the public.Vogel, Steve, "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/08/26/AR2009082603606.html For Intelligence Officers, A Wiki Way to Connect Dots]", ''[[Washington Post]]'', August 27, 2009, p. 23. Intellipedia is a project of the [[Office of the Director of National Intelligence]] (ODNI) [[Intelink|Intelligence Community Enterprise Services]] (ICES) office headquartered in [[Fort George G. Meade|Fort Meade]], [[Maryland]]. It includes information on the regions, people, and issues of interest to the communities using its host networks. Intellipedia uses [[MediaWiki]], the same software used by the [[Wikipedia]] free-content encyclopedia project.{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2006/November/Pages/SecurityBeat2819.aspx?PF=1 |title=Wikipedia for Intel Officers Proves Useful |work=National Defense Magazine |date=November 2006 |accessdate=2006-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IvkVRnyJ?url=http://www.nationaldefensemagazine.org/archive/2006/November/Pages/SecurityBeat2819.aspx?PF=1 |archivedate=2013-08-17 |df= }} To the contrary of mainstream ''Wikipedia'', its intelligence analogue encourages editing that incorporates personal points of view regardless of rank as it was decided that, "much of the self-corrective knowledge in the Intelligence Community resides in personal points of view," and that, "not all good ideas originate at the top." The Secret version connected to SIPRNet predominantly serves [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] and the [[United States Department of State|Department of State]] personnel, many of whom do not use the Top Secret JWICS network on a day-to-day basis. Users on unclassified networks can access Intellipedia from remote terminals outside their workspaces via a [[VPN]], in addition to their normal workstations. [[Open Source Intelligence]] (OSINT) users share information on the unclassified Intelink-U wiki. ==History== Intellipedia was created to share information on some of the most difficult subjects facing U.S. intelligence and to bring cutting-edge technology into its ever-more-youthful workforce.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/news/techinnovations/2006-11-02-intellipedia_x.htm |title=Over 3,600 intelligence professionals tapping into Intellipedia |work=[[USA Today]] |agency=Associated Press |first=Katherine |last=Shrader |date=2006-02-11 |accessdate=2008-10-27}} It also allows information to be assembled and reviewed by a wide variety of sources and agencies, to address concerns that pre-war intelligence did not include robust dissenting opinions on Iraq's alleged weapons programs.[http://www.smartbrief.com/alchemy/servlet/encodeServlet?issueid=53427FBF-AE22-4442-B244-C4E7C872397A&lmid=archives "Data from spies now assembled wiki-style"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', November 1, 2006 A number of projects are under way to explore the use of the Intellipedia for the creation of traditional Intelligence Community products. In the summer of 2006, Intellipedia was the main collaboration tool in constructing a [[National Intelligence Estimate]] on [[Nigeria]].Bruce Finley, [http://www.denverpost.com/search/ci_4216851 "Intelligence Fixes Floated at Conference," ''Denver Post'', 08/22/2006] Intellipedia was at least partially inspired by a paper written for the [[Galileo Award]] (an essay competition set up by the CIA, later taken over by the DNI), which encouraged any employee at any intelligence agency to submit new ideas to improve information sharing. The first essay selected was by [[Calvin Andrus]], chief technology officer of the Center for Mission Innovation at the CIA, entitled "The Wiki and the Blog: Toward a Complex Adaptive Intelligence Community". Andrus' essay argued that the real power of the Internet had come from the boom in self-publishing, and noted how the open-door policy of [[Wikipedia]] allowed it to cover new subjects quickly.D. Calvin Andrus, Ph.D. Office of Application Services, Central Intelligence Agency. [http://www.acadac.net/wiki/images/a/af/SSRN-id755904.pdf The wiki and the blog: Toward a complex adaptive intelligence community], ''Studies in Intelligence'', Volume 49, Number 3, September 2005. Published on the Web as, {{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/csi-studies/studies/vol49no3/html_files/Wik_and_%20Blog_7.htm |title=The wiki and the blog: Toward a complex adaptive intelligence community|author=D. Calvin Andrus |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency Center for the Study of Intelligence |accessdate=2008-05-02}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/03/magazine/03intelligence.html |title=Open-Source Spying |author=Clive Thompson |work=The New York Times Magazine|date=2006-12-03|accessdate=2007-11-17}} Richard A. Russell, Deputy Assistant [[Director of National Intelligence]] for [[Information Sharing Customer Outreach (ISCO)]] said it was created so "analysts in different agencies that work X or Y can go in and see what other people are doing on subject X or Y and actually add in their two cents worth ... or documents that they have. ... What we're after here is 'decision superiority', not 'information superiority'. ... We have to get inside the decision cycle of the enemy. We have to be able to discover what they're doing and respond to it effectively." In September 2007, sixteen months after its creation, officials noted that the top-secret version of Intellipedia alone (hosted on [[Joint Worldwide Intelligence Communications System|JWICS]]) has 29,255 articles, with an average of 114 new articles and more than 6,000 edits to articles added each workday.{{cite news|first=Scott|last=Shane|title=Logged In and Sharing Gossip, Er, Intelligence|date=September 2, 2007|work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/02/weekinreview/02shane.html}} As of April 2009, the overall Intellipedia project hosted 900,000 pages edited by 100,000 users, with 5,000 page edits per day.{{cite news |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1890084,00.html |title=Wikipedia for Spies: The CIA Discovers Web 2.0 |work=Time |date=2009-04-08 |accessdate=2009-04-09 |first=Massimo |last=Calabresi}} As of January 2014, Intellipedia contained around 269,000 articlesKaven Waddel. [https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2017/03/the-governments-secret-wiki-for-intelligence/518508/?google_editors_picks=true The Government’s Secret Wiki for Intelligence: Analysts reportedly tucked classified information about Russian hacking inside Intellipedia for safekeeping,] ''The Atlantic,'' March 3, 2017. with the Top Secret Intellipedia counting 113,000 content pages with 255,000 users.{{cite web|last=jasonsmathers|url=https://www.muckrock.com/foi/united-states-of-america-10/intellipedia-usage-statistics-10058/|title=FOIA request for Intellipedia usage statistics|publisher=MuckRock|accessdate=10 April 2014}} ===10 years later=== A 2017 two-part ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' series on Intellipedia and next steps reported that after 10 years of usage Intellipedia helped the IC get caught up to "Web 2.0" but never reformed how official reports were created like [[National Intelligence Estimate]]s. A more official version of Intellipedia called the Living Intelligence System was created after the fact and focused on collaboratively writing official reports. It failed to catch on because each agency has a different process for writing official, classified reports.[https://www.wired.com/2017/03/intellipedia-wikipedia-spies-much/ The Wikipedia for Spies and Where It Goes From Here], Wired, March 2017 Based on the lessons learned from Intellipedia and the Living Intelligence System, a pilot program within the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency created the Tearline apps focused on writing official collaborative reports in the less bureaucratic space of unclassified content.[https://www.wired.com/2017/04/american-spies-now-smartphone-app/ American Spies Now Have Their Own Smartphone App], Wired, April 2017 ==Potential problems== Some are concerned that individual intelligence agencies will create their own wikis, draining ideas and input from Intellipedia.{{cite web|url=http://www.marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2006/11/intellipedia.html#comment-25336444|title=Intellipedia - Marginal REVOLUTION|date=2 November 2006|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}} Sean Dennehy, a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] official involved in integrating the system into the intelligence fabric, said disseminating material to the widest possible audience of analysts is key to avoiding mistakes. He said analysts from multiple agencies had used the network to post frequent updates on recent events, including [[2006 New York City plane crash|the crash of a small plane into a New York City apartment building in October 2006]] and [[2006 North Korean missile test|North Korea's test of a missile in July 2006]].{{cite web|url=http://esenai.com/blog/intellipedia/people/michael_wertheimer/|title=Intellipedia Roundtable Discussion|website=esenai.com}} Some view it as risky because it allows more information to be viewed and shared;{{cite web|url=http://esenai.com/blog/intellipedia/|title=U.S. intelligence unveils spy version of Wikipedia|website=esenai.com}} but according to [[Michael Wertheimer]], [[John Michael McConnell|McConnell's]] assistant deputy director for analysis, it is worth the risk. The project was greeted initially with "a lot of resistance," said Wertheimer, because it runs counter to past practice which sought to limit the pooling of information.{{cite web|url=http://www.metimes.com/storyview.php?StoryID=20061103-075107-4557r|title=US spies create their own 'Wiki' intelligence|website=metimes.com}} He said there are risks in everything everyone does: "the key is risk management, not risk avoidance." Some encouragement has been necessary to spur contributions from the traditional intelligence community. However, he said the system appeals to the new generation of intelligence analysts because "this is how they like to work" and "it's a new way of thinking." ==Successes== [[File:Intellipedia2008.png|thumb|[[2008 Mumbai attacks]] page on Intellipedia]] [[Thomas Fingar]], [[Director of National Intelligence|Deputy Director of National Intelligence for Analysis]] (DDNI/A), cited the successful use of Intellipedia to develop an article on how Iraqi insurgents were using [[chlorine]] in [[improvised explosive devices]] saying, "They developed it in a couple of days interacting in Intellipedia,"..."No bureaucracy, no mother-may-I, no convening meetings. They did it and it came out pretty good. That's going to continue to grow."[http://defensenews.com/story.php?F=2733832&C=america "U.S. Intel Agencies Modernize Info Sharing", ''DefenseNews.com'', May 7, 2007][http://www.dni.gov/speeches/20070905_speech.pdf 2007 Analytic Transformation Symposium], 6 September 2007, p. 13 In a September 10, 2007 testimony before the [[United States Congress]], [[John Michael McConnell|Michael McConnell]], [[Director of National Intelligence]], cited the increasing use of Intellipedia among analysts and its ability to help experts pool their knowledge, form virtual teams, and make quick assessments.[http://dni.gov/testimonies/20070910_testimony.pdf Michael McConnell. "Confronting the Terrorist Threat to the Homeland: Six Years after 9/11]", ''Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee'', September 10, 2007 ''[[Analyzing Intelligence: Origins, Obstacles, and Innovations]]'', a 2008 book by several experts in the field of intelligence analysis, cited Intellipedia as evidence of the changing nature of analysis.Roger George, James Bruce, et al., ''Analyzing Intelligence: Origins, Obstacles, and Innovations'', Georgtown University Press, April 2008 [[Eric Haseltine]], former ODNI Associate Director for Science and Technology said that "It's hard to overstate what [Burke and Dennehy] did . ... They made a major transformation almost overnight with no money after other programs failed to achieve these results with millions of dollars in funding." Haseltine said intelligence analysts had "reacted 'more quickly and more intelligently' to potential terrorist threats than they would have without Intellipedia". ==Community practices== [[File:Intellipedia shovel.jpg|thumb|An Intellipedia shovel, awarded to exemplary wiki contributors.]] The wiki provides so much flexibility that several offices throughout the community are using it to maintain and transfer knowledge on daily operations and events.Executive Biz, [http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=jwilson Executive Spotlight with Jesse Wilson], October 11, 2007 Anyone with access to read it has permission to create and edit articles after registering and acquiring an account with [[Intelink]]. Since Intellipedia is intended to be a platform for harmonizing the various points of view of the agencies and analysts of the Intelligence Community, Intellipedia does not enforce a [[neutrality (philosophy)|neutral point of view]] policy.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/03/magazine/03intelligence.html?ex=1322802000&en=46027e63d79046ce&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss|title=Open-Source Spying|work=New York Times Magazine|date=December 2006|accessdate=2006-12-03 |first=Clive |last=Thompson}} Instead, viewpoints are attributed to the agencies, offices, and individuals participating, with the hope that a consensus view will emerge. Intellipedia also contains a great deal of non-encyclopedic content including meeting notes and items of internal, administrative interest. Deputy DNI [[Thomas Fingar]] made a comparison to [[eBay]], the auction Web site where the reliability of sellers is rated by buyers. He said:
Intellipedia. It's been written up. It's the Wikipedia on a classified network, with one very important difference: it's not anonymous. We want people to establish a reputation. If you're really good, we want people to know you're good. If you're making contributions, we want that known. If you're an idiot, we want that known too.{{cite web|url=http://www.cfr.org/publication/15754/intelligence_reform_rush_transcript_federal_news_service.html|title=Intelligence Reform [Rush Transcript; Federal News Service]|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}}{{cite news |first=Mazzetti |last=Mark |title=Intelligence Chief Announces Renewed Plan for Overhaul |date=April 12, 2007 |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/12/washington/12intel.html}}
During 2006–2007, Intellipedia editors awarded symbolic ''shovels'' to users to distinguish exemplary Wiki ''gardening'' and to encourage others in the community to contribute. A template with a picture of the limited-edition shovel (actually a trowel), was created to place on user pages for Intellipedians to show their ''gardening'' status. The handle bears the imprint: "I dig Intellipedia! It's wiki wiki, Baby." The idea was inspired by the [[Wikipedia:Barnstars|barnstar]],{{cite web |url=http://www.eekim.com/blog/2006/09/27/intellipediashovel |title=EEK Speaks |work=Eugene Eric Kim's Blog |accessdate=2006-11-01}} which is used on both [[Wikipedia:Barnstars|Wikipedia]] and [[MeatballWiki]] for similar purposes. The shovels have since been replaced with a mug bearing the tag line, "Intellipedia: it's what we know". Different agencies have experimented with other ways of encouraging participation. For example, at the CIA, managers have held contests for best pages with prizes such as free dinners.{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com/action/article.do?command=viewArticleBasic&articleId=9096658&pageNumber=1 |title=CIA, Pfizer, Wachovia and Sony execs suggest options for adopting Web 2.0 |author=Heather Havenstein |publisher=Computerworld}} Chris Rasmussen, knowledge management officer at the Defense Department's [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] (NGA), argues that "gimmicks" like the Intellipedia shovel, posters, and handbills, encourage people to use [[Web 2.0]] tools like Intellipedia and are effective low-tech solutions to promote their use. Also, Rasmussen argues that "[[social software]]–based contributions should be written in an employee's performance plan"."[http://www.fcw.com/print/13_16/news/102750-1.html Government taps the power of us: Officials turn to blogs and wikis to share information and achieve goals]", ''Federal Computer Week'', May 21, 2007 ===Training=== Several agencies in the Intelligence community, most notably the CIA and NGA,{{cite web|url=http://blog.executivebiz.com/web20-adoption-in-large-enterprises/|title=Web2.0 Adoption in Large Enterprises|publisher=|accessdate=30 August 2016}} have developed training programs to provide time to integrate social software tools into analysts' daily work habits. These classes generally focus on the use of Intellipedia to capture and manage knowledge, but they also incorporate the use of the other social software tools. These include [[blog]]s, [[RSS]], and social bookmarking. The courses stress immersion in the tools and instructors encourage participants to work on a specific project in Intellipedia. The courses also expose participants to social media technologies on the Internet.[http://www.federalnewsradio.com/?sid=1286296&nid=250 Radio interview] that highlights Intelligence Community social software training programs, Federal News Radio, November 5, 2007[http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=sdennehy Executive Spotlight Interview with Sean Dennehy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206042130/http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=sdennehy |date=2008-12-06 }}, ExecutiveBiz, December 5, 2007[http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=crasmussen Executive Spotlight Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204094209/http://www.executivebiz.com/newsletter-executives-detail.php?who=crasmussen |date=2008-12-04 }} with Chris Rasmussen, ExecutiveBiz, October 25, 2007 ==Awards== In 2009, Don Burke and Sean P. Dennehy, two of the originators of Intellipedia, were awarded with the "Homeland Security Service to America Medal" by the [[Partnership for Public Service]]. The award noted that they "Promoted information sharing across the intelligence community through the development and implementation of Intellipedia, a Wikipedia-like clearinghouse of intelligence expertise."{{cite web|url=http://servicetoamericamedals.org/honorees/view_profile.php?profile=215|title=2009 'Service to America Medal Recipients' |accessdate=2010-01-05 |publisher=[[Service to America Medals]] |date=2009-09-23}} ==See also== * [[A-Space]] * [[Bureaupedia]]—the FBI's online encyclopedia * [[Classified website]] * [[Diplopedia]] * [[DoDTechipedia]] * [[Intellipublia]] ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} ==Further reading== * Frank Ahrens. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/03/AR2006110302015.html "A Wikipedia of secrets"], ''The Washington Post'', November 5, 2006. * D. Calvin Andrus, Ph.D. Office of Application Services, Central Intelligence Agency. [https://ssrn.com/abstract=755904 The wiki and the blog: Toward a complex adaptive intelligence community], ''Studies in Intelligence'', Volume 49, Number 3, September 2005. * Cody Burke. [http://epublications.bond.edu.au/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1010&context=cewces_papers Freeing knowledge, telling secrets: Open source intelligence and development], ''CEWCES Research Papers,'' Bond University, May 2007. * Matthew S. Burton. [https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/csi-studies/studies/vol49no3/html_files/Intelligence_Networking_6.htm Connecting the Virtual Dots: How the Web Can Relieve Our Information Glut and Get Us Talking to Each Other], ''Studies in Intelligence'', Vol 49, Number 3, September 2005. * Gianluigi Cesta. [http://gnosis.aisi.gov.it/Gnosis/Rivista10.nsf/ServNavigE/7 The Intellipedia experiment or rather, shared secrets], ''Gnosis (Italian Intelligence magazine of [[Agenzia Informazioni e Sicurezza Interna|AISI]]),'' No. 1, 2007. * Wilson P. Dizard III. [https://gcn.com/articles/2006/09/22/spy-agencies-adapt-social-software-federated-search-tools.aspx Spy agencies adapt social software, federated search tools], ''Government Computer News'', September 25, 2006. * [http://uk.reuters.com/article/tech-internet-intelligence-dc-idUKN0123738920061031 "U.S. intelligence unveils spy version of Wikipedia"], ''Reuters'', October 31, 2006. * Scott Shane. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/02/weekinreview/02shane.html Logged In and Sharing Gossip, er, Intelligence], ''The New York Times,'' September 2, 2007. ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://www.intelink.gov/wiki Official Intellipedia website] (may require an [https://www.intelink.gov/passport/servlet/PassportLogin Intelink Passport account]) * [http://www.theblackvault.com/documentarchive/intellipedia-entries/# Declassified Intellipedia Entries] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20170305032038/http://www.theblackvault.com/documentarchive/intellipedia-entries/# Archive]) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130729204530/http://itc.conversationsnetwork.org/shows/detail1891.html Jon Udell's Interviews with Innovators], Audio interview with Lewis Shepherd of the Defense Intelligence Agency about Intellipedia and Web 2.0 use within the US Intelligence Community. August 2, 2007. * Chris Rasmussen. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nbgQ1V2BLEs Toward Living Intelligence], YouTube presentation discussing the role of Intellipedia for Intelligence Community, June 2, 2009. {{United States intelligence agencies}} [[Category:2006 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Enterprise wikis]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2006]] [[Category:MediaWiki sites of the United States government]] [[Category:Open-source intelligence]] [[Category:United States intelligence agencies]] [[Category:Academic works about intelligence analysis]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox company |name = Global Research & Analytics - IREVNA, a division of CRISIL |logo = IrevnaLogo.gif |logo_size = 110px |type = [[Division (organisation)|Division]] |foundation = 2001 |location = [[Chennai]], [[India]] |key_people = V Srinivasan |num_employees = 1500 (as of 2012 end) |industry = [[Offshoring / Global Research & Analytics]] |parent = [[CRISIL]] |products = Financial Services
Risk and Analytics
Corporate Services |homepage = [http://www.crisil.com/gra CRISIL GR&A] }} '''Global Research & Analytics - Irevna''' is an offshoring company based in [[India]] operating in the Financial Research & Analytics segment of the [[Knowledge Process Outsourcing]] (KPO) industry. It is known for its equity, credit, derivatives research for investment banking clients, actuarial support for the insurance companies and research support for corporates. According to Datamonitor's The Black Book of Outsourcing, survey participants ranked Irevna #1 in 14 of the 18 evaluation criteria [2009] Founded in 2001, it is now a division of [[CRISIL]] Ltd ([[National Stock Exchange of India|NSE]]:CRISIL, [[Bombay Stock Exchange|BSE]]:500092). CRISIL’s majority shareholder is [[Standard & Poor's]], a division of The [[McGraw-Hill Financial]] Companies and one of the world's providers of financial market intelligence. In September 2010, CRISIL-Irevna signed an agreement to acquire Chicago-based Pipal Research Corporation (Pipal), another player in the KPO space for a consideration of $12.75 million. This marked the first acquisition of a KPO firm by a third party pure-play KPO firm. According to CEO of CRISIL Ltd, the acquisition was completely complementary in terms of research centers, business development centres and service offerings.:http://www.irevna.com/pdf/CRISIL-Irevna%20buys%20Pipal%20Research%20-%2022%20September%202010.pdf/686206 In June 2012, CRISIL GR&A acquired UK-headquartered Coalition Development Ltd. along with its subsidiaries (Coalition).Coalition provides high-end analytics, mainly to leading global investment banks. A change from the earlier GR&A service company acquisitions), Coalition, a premium product based company, was formed in 2002 and reported 2011 revenues of GBP 8 million. Subject to conditions, the acquisition was CRISIL GR&A's largest at the time of announcement and payout could reach GBP 29 million over 2 years.:http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/crisil-research/crisil-to-acquire-coalition-uk-based-analytics-firm_712123.html ==Structure== ===Ownership Structure=== Global Research & Analytics-Irevna is a division of CRISIL, India's leading ratings, research, risk and policy advisory company. CRISIL's offerings includes credit ratings and risk assessment; research on India's economy, industries and companies; investment research outsourcing; fund services; risk management and infrastructure advisory services. CRISIL's majority shareholder is Standard & Poor's, a McGraw-Hill Company. [[File:Ownership.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Irevna Ownership Structure]] ===Offerings=== Global Research & Analytics-Irevna offers services (excluding Coalition) in the following verticals:http://www.irevna.com/services.html {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" ! Financial Services |- |Equity Research |- |Credit Research |- |FX and Economics |- |Commodity Research |- |Buy-side Support |} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" ! Risk and Analytics |- |Derivatives Support |- |Financial Technology |- |Quantitative Analytics |- |Risk Management Analytics |- |Insurance Actuarial Services |} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" ! Corporate Services |- |Strategy and M&A Support |- |Business Research |- |Competitive Intelligence |- |Market Research and Intelligence |- |Investor Relations Services |} ===Location=== The company has multiple research centres and sales offices across the world. The main research centres are located in: # '''[[Mumbai]]''', India: Irevna has two research centres in Mumbai. The first one caters to Fixed Income and credit research; while a second newly built office caters towards Equity and Derivative research. The centre is located near its parent CRISIL Ltd. # '''[[Chennai]]''', India: The original research centre of the company. There are three offices located in various parts of the city. The delivery centres in Chennai cater to European, North American and Asia-PAC clients. The Chennai offices primarily conduct Equity, Derivative and Quantitative research. The latest delivery centre was operational from 2007 onwards.[http://www.click2map.com/maps/ARUNN/Map1 Map] [http://www.moneycontrol.com/india/news/press--news/irevna-setsits-3rd-delivery-center-at-santhome-chennai/296710 Moneycontrol India :: News :: Irevna sets up its 3rd delivery center at Santhome, Chennai :: :: Press- News :: Irevna,offshore equity ,investment research] # '''[[Pune]]''': Irevna opened another research centre in the city of Pune in 2011. This center caters to all the research verticals of the CRISIL GR&A group, in addition to other divisions of CRISIL # '''[[Delhi]]''': This center was acquired as a result of the Pipal acquisition and houses the corporate research and support vertical. Multiples centers at Gurgaon and Pipal were consolidated into one facility at Gurgaon in 2012 # '''[[Buenos Aires]]''', Argentina: The Argentina research centre was opened with the intention of providing real time support for North American operations. The team focuses primarily on equity and credit research. [http://wikimapia.org/3298446/Irevna_Argentina Map][http://www.irevna.com.ar/ Irevna] # '''[[Wroclaw]]''','''[[Poland]]''': Poland research centre focus on Quantitative Research. #'''[[Hangzhou]]''','''[[China]]''': The China research centre started in 2011 and caters to clients requiring research support in East Asian languages. Services provided include Primary Research support, in addition to Equity and Credit research. This above locations doesn't include Coalition Offices. ==Other information== ===History=== Founded in 2001, the company was initially known as Irevna Solutions Private Limited and was based out of [[Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh|Hyderabad]], [[India]]. The company relocated to [[Chennai]] in 2003 and was renamed Irevna Research Services Pvt. Ltd. In 2005, [[CRISIL]] announced its intention to purchase Irevna Research Services for an initial cash payment of about Rs 43 crores (Approx US$8.6 Million, based on then USD-INR exchange rate).[http://www.thehindubusinessline.in/2004/10/20/stories/2004102002710100.htm The Hindu Business Line : Crisil buys Irevna for Rs 43 cr] The company has since been rechristened as '''Irevna, a division of Crisil'''. Subsequently in 2011, the global research support units of CRISIL have been rebranded as "CRISIL - Global Research and Analytics" (Irevna and Pipal serve as exclusive brands for external clients; and a Captive unit) Irevna moved to Chennai in 2002 with about 20 people. At the start of 2010, the Chennai operations alone have grown over 25 times and accounts for around 40% of CRISIL's global offshoring operations.[http://www.irevna.com/pdf/Irevna%20is%20constantly%20redefining%20KPO%20landscape,%20ET%20interview%20-%20April%202010.pdf Irevna is constantly redefining KPO landscape, ET interview - April 2010] Irevna claims to have pioneered the concept of "offshoring investment research" to the world's leading investment banks and financial institutions.[http://www.allbusiness.com/company-activities-management/company-strategy-outsourcing/5284944-1.html Mr. GV Mani Named Global Head of CRISIL Irevna Group's Offshoring Business. | Company Activities & Management > Company Strategy from AllBusiness.com] The company became ISO 27001 (BS 7799) certified in November 2006. ===Recognition & Awards=== The company has been consistently ranked the best outsourcer in its niche segment of high end financial research & analytics space. {| class="wikitable collapsible sortable" !Year!!Rank!!Category |- |2009||1|||Financial Services Provider |- |2009||1|||Corporate Finance Support & Advisory |- |2009||1|||Risk Management & Actuarial Services |- |2009||1|||Financial Services Analytics |- |2008||2|||Financial Services Industry Analytics |- |2007||1|||Financial Services Industry Analytics |- |2006||1|||Investment Research Outsourcing |} Sourced: Datamonitor-Black Book of Outsourcing [http://www.datamonitor.com/store/Product/2009_the_black_book_of_outsourcing_state_of_the_outsourcing_industry_report?productid=20109D4A-5FE1-4E55-96EE-E6E9AE6C0F84] ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.irevna.com/ Irevna Site - longer updated] *[http://www.Crisil.com/gra/ CRISIL GR&A Site] *[http://www.Crisil.com/ CRISIL Site] [[Category:Companies based in Chennai]] [[Category:Offshoring]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Konstantin Chomu Film.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Konstantin Chomu in Bitola at 1931.]] '''Konstantin Čomu''' (1865–1952), often credited as '''Kosta Chomu''' ([[Macedonian language|Macedonian Cyrillic]]: Константин Чому) or '''Konstantin Comu''' was a [[Vlach]] ([[Aromanian people]]) cinema operator, first in [[Bitola]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]. == Work== The appearance of the cinema in Macedonia dates from the beginning of the 20th century. Ten years after the promotion of this new art at the Grande Caffe in [[Paris]] (1895), the cinema arrived in Macedonian soil, thus marking the expansion of the new medium. The first projection took place as early as 1896, and by the beginning of the 20th century they grew frequent. An increasing number of projectors were owned and operated by certain progressive individuals. At the Balkan, such a person was Konstantin Chomu from Bitola. Konstantin Chomu opened and operated the first cinema center in Bitola. Among other world wide famous movies, he was projecting the shots and films made from the famous [[Manaki brothers]]. ==References== 1. http://www.macedonia.co.uk/client/index1.aspx?page=26
2. http://www.orbis.com.mk/Photography_and__film_activity.htm
3. http://www.unet.com.mk/mian/macult.htm
4. https://web.archive.org/web/20070707112205/http://www.thealbanians.com/cinema/index.htm {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chomu, Konstantin}} [[Category:1865 births]] [[Category:1952 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bitola]] [[Category:Macedonian businesspeople]] [[Category:Macedonian film people]] [[Category:Aromanian people]]

page.title: List of business schools in the United States

revision.text:
This is a '''list of business schools in the United States'''. Business schools are listed in alphabetical order by state, then name. Schools named after people are alphabetized by last name. Accreditation bodies for business schools in the United States include [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB), [[Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs]] (ACBSP), and [[International Assembly for Collegiate Business Education]] (IACBE). This list is sortable. Click on the boxes next to the attribute names to sort the list by state, school, parent university, etc. {{dynamic list}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! State ! School ! College ! City ! [[AACSB]] accreditation ! revision.comment: not orphaned

migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Maurice Dollfus|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Maurice Dollfus''' was appointed to head up [[Ford SAF|Ford of France]] in 1930. Four years later he negotiated an agreement with [[Mathis (cars)|Mathis]] which led to the creation of the [[Matford]] joint project in 1934 in order to enable Ford to grow its French business at a time of [[mercantilism|increased protectionism]] and at an acceptable cost. When the [[Matford]] partnership fell apart it was Dollfus who created Ford’s new [[PSA Poissy Plant|plant at Poissy]] which was ready to produce cars in 1940 and which allowed the company an impressive annual production capacity (that would never be reached while Ford owned the plant) of 100,000 cars.
Like many industrialists Dollfus was arrested in September 1944, suspected of collaboration in the fevered period of retribution that directly followed the [[:fr: Libération de la France|Liberation]], and he was transferred to [[Drancy internment camp|Drancy]] (where he met [[Sacha Guitry]]). However he was quickly released and in 1945 received from the Americans an award reserved for companies that had contributed to the allied victory.
After 1945 he continued to lead Ford in France, obtaining from the Americans a ready developed new model that became the future [[Ford Vedette]]. However, aged 66 he quit Ford in January 1950 after presiding over the difficult gestation period of the Vedette, during which the company was troubled by serious industrial strife as well as the huge challenges that faced all auto-makers in France during the later 1940s. Dollfus was succeeded at Ford by [[François Lehideux]], who was both a former [[Renault]] plant manager and a former minister under the [[Vichy France|Vichy regime]].
== External links == * [http://dvole.free.fr/matford/ Matford constructeur automobile français 1934-1941] * [http://dvole.free.fr/fordsaf/fordsaf.htm Ford Société Anonyme Française - Poissy] * [http://www.caapy.net Collection de l'Aventure Automobile à Poissy (CAAPY)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lefacheux Pierre}} [[Category:Ford people]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:1885 births]] [[Category:Year of death missing]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Middle East Public Relations Association
جمعية الشرق الأوسط للعلاقات العامة | former name = | image = | image_border = | size = | alt = | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = MEPRA | motto = | predecessor = | formation = | extinction = | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Abu Dhabi]] | location = [[UAE]] | coords = | region_served = | membership = | general = | leader_title = President | leader_name = Mazen Nahawi | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | affiliations = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|http://www.mepra.org/}} | remarks = }} The '''Middle East Public Relations Association''' ('''MEPRA''') is a non-profit organisation, that represents the interests of the [[Middle East]] [[public relations]] industry. It is registed at [[Abu Dhabi]] in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. MEPRA's purpose is to highlight the strategic role of public relations in the [[Arab world]] and help set high standards for quality and ethical conduct by consultancy firms.{{cite web |url= http://gulfnews.com/business/media-marketing/tougher-guidelines-in-place-for-region-s-pr-industry-awards-1.1044493 |title=Tougher guidelines in place for region's PR industry awards | GulfNews.com|work=gulfnews.com|accessdate=15 November 2012}} The Association provides a single point of contact for government, the business community and the media to talk to the region's growing PR industry. As of June 2008, MEPRA's membership consisted of 26 public relations firms with nearly 100 offices in more than 14 Arab states. MEPRA is a member of the International Committee of Public Relations Consultancies Associations (ICCO), which represents PR consultancies across 29 countries. MEPRA hosts an annual awards ceremony for PR companies in the Middle East.{{cite web |url= http://www.edelman.com/post/middle-east-pr-association-mepra-updates-awards-judging-criteria/ |title=Edelman - Middle East PR Association (MEPRA) Updates Awards’ Judging Criteria|work=edelman.com|accessdate=15 November 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.mepra.org}} [[Category:Business organisations based in the United Arab Emirates]]

page.title: Militant use of children in Sri Lanka

revision.comment: Surrender figure
revision.text:
{{Child soldiers}} '''Militant use of children in Sri Lanka''' has been an internationally recognized problem since the inception of the [[Sri Lankan civil war]] in 1983. The primary recruiters of under the age of 18 children are the rebel [[LTTE]] movement and the [[Karuna group]] (a break-away faction of the LTTE working with Sri Lanka Forces).<ref name=UNICEF20060622>{{cite press release |title=UNICEF condemns abduction and recruitment of Sri Lankan children by the Karuna group |publisher=[[UNICEF]] |date=2006-06-22 |url=http://www.unicef.org/media/media_34677.html |accessdate=2008-07-16}}</ref><ref name=rediff20050126>{{cite news|title=Tsunami orphans swell LTTE ranks |url=http://in.rediff.com/news/2005/jan/26ltte.htm |publisher=Rediff.com India Limited |date=2005-01-26 |accessdate=2008-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050907141326/http://in.rediff.com/news/2005/jan/26ltte.htm |archivedate=September 7, 2005 }}</ref><ref name=irandaily20050127>{{cite news|title=Sri Lankan Rebels Recruiting Child Soldiers |url=http://www.iran-daily.com/1383/2201/pdf/9-politic.pdf |format=PDF |work=Iran Daily |page=9 |date=2005-01-27 |accessdate=2008-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930184434/http://www.iran-daily.com/1383/2201/pdf/9-politic.pdf |archivedate=September 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=sfchron20060917>{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Meo |title=Tamil Tigers abduct teens to fight |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2006/09/17/MNGIPL6N391.DTL&feed=rss.news |work=San Francisco Chronicle |page=A17 |date=2006-09-17 |accessdate=2008-07-16}}</ref>
==LTTE recruitment== Before 2007 the LTTE was accused of recruiting thousands of children into their ranks. The LTTE has been accused of knowingly recruiting and using child soldiers as front-line troops. Amid international pressure, LTTE announced in July 2003 that it would stop conscripting child soldiers, but both UNICEF and HRW have accused it of reneging on its promises, and of conscripting Tamil children orphaned by the tsunami. UNICEF claimed that LTTE recruited at least 40 children orphaned by the tsunami.<ref name=rediff20050126 /> However, from the beginning of 2007 LTTE agreed to release all of the recruits under the age of 18.
===2007=== According to UNICEF, between November 1, 2006 and August 31, 2007, 262 children were recruited by the LTTE; this figure includes 32 children who were rerecruited after being released. This number shows a significant decrease in recruitment as compared to the previous 12-month period, which saw the LTTE recruit 756 children, of whom 97 were rerecruits.<ref>[http://www.app.com.pk/en/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=24745&Itemid=2 Associated Press of Pakistan - Sri Lankan rebels still recruiting child soldiers : UN chief<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The LTTE promised that it would release all of the recruits under the age of 18 before the end of the year. On 18 June 2007, the LTTE released 135 children under the age of 18. On 22 October 2007, [[UNICEF]] claimed that at least 506 child recruits (under the age of 18) still remained under the LTTE. UNICEF further noted that there had been a significant drop in recruitment of children by the LTTE.<ref>[http://web.amnesty.org/library/index/engASA370172007?open&of=eng-LKA Sri Lanka: Amnesty International urges LTTE to live up to its pledge to end child recruitment | Amnesty International<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071022100510/http://web.amnesty.org/library/Index/ENGASA370172007?open&of=ENG-LKA |date=2007-10-22 }}</ref> Furthermore, a report released by the LTTE's Child Protection Authority (CPA) in 2008 reported that fewer than 40 child soldiers, under the age of 18, still remained in their forces.<ref>[http://www.ltteps.org/?view=2095&folder=17 LTTE PS: Status of UNICEF database on underage LTTE members<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716163102/http://www.ltteps.org/?view=2095&folder=17 |date=2011-07-16 }}</ref> In January 2008, the LTTE claimed that they had stopped child recruitment.<ref name="The Hindu News Update Service">{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/holnus/001200801311401.htm |location=Chennai, India |work=The Hindu |title=Karuna faction recruiting child soldiers in Lanka: UN |date=2008-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121107152624/http://www.hindu.com/holnus/001200801311401.htm |archivedate=2012-11-07 |df= }}</ref> Despite the LTTE claims according to the UNICEF a total of 594 children aged between 12 and 18 years surrendered to armed forces during the end of the war.<ref>{{cite news |title=Once a child soldier now an ice-creme truck driver |url=https://www.unicef.org/srilanka/reallives_7924.html |accessdate=7 August 2018 |agency=UNICEF}}</ref>
==TMVP Paramilitary Recruitment== More recently, [[TMVP]] known as the [[Karuna Group]] (A Tamil paramilitary group which supports the Sri Lankan government), has been held responsible for the abduction of children according to [[UNICEF]] and [[Human Rights Watch]].<ref name=HRN20061128>{{cite press release |title=Sri Lanka: Stop Child Abductions by Karuna Group |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |date=2006-11-28 |url=https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2006/11/28/slanka14678.htm |accessdate=2008-07-16}}</ref> [[Allan Rock]], who is a special advisor to the UN Special Rapporteur for Children and Armed Conflict Dr. Radhika Coomaraswamy, alleged<ref name=BBC20061113>{{cite news |title=Sri Lanka youth 'seized to fight' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6144200.stm |work=[[BBC News]] |date=2006-11-13 |accessdate=2008-07-16}}</ref> that government forces had forcibly rounded up young Tamil children to fight with Col Karuna's group. [[Colonel Karuna]], while categorically denying any involvement in abducting children, questioned Rock's impartiality, stating that Allan Rock is a former politician with links to the LTTE who had previously helped the LTTE in Canada.<ref name=AT20061127>{{cite news |title=Solheim in the pay of Tigers: his house in Norway bought with Tiger money - Col. Karuna |url=http://www.asiantribune.com/index.php?q=node/3418 |work=Asian Tribune |date=2006-11-27 |accessdate=2008-07-16}}</ref> Civilians have also complained that the TMVP is continuing to abduct children, including some in their early teens, for use as soldiers.<ref name=sfchron20060917 /> Allan Rock vowed that he had "credible evidence" for the accusations.<ref name=BBC20061113 /> The government of Sri Lanka and the Government newspaper ''[[Daily News (Sri Lanka)|Daily News]]'' asked Mr. Rock to produce substantive proof that Sri Lankan soldiers collaborated in child soldier recruitment.<ref name=daily20061123>{{cite news |first=Asoka |last=Weerasinghe |title=Slice your defence whichever way |url=http://www.dailynews.lk/2006/11/23/fea01.asp |work=Daily News |publisher=The Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Ltd |date=2006-11-23 |accessdate=2008-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081215033652/http://www.dailynews.lk/2006/11/23/fea01.asp |archivedate=2008-12-15 |df= }}</ref> The new report by the [[United Nations]] stated that [[TMVP]] still recruits children. The [[UN]] further noted that children have been abducted in places like Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) camps in Sri Lanka.<ref name="The Hindu News Update Service"/>
==See also== *[[Military use of children]] *[[Government of Sri Lanka]] *[[LTTE]] *[[Colonel Karuna]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Sri Lankan Civil War}}

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Mohammed Jamal Khalifa | image = MohammedJamalKhalifa.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date|1957|2|1|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2007|1|31|1957|2|1|df=y}} | death_place = [[Madagascar]] | occupation = Businessman }}
'''Mohammed Jamal Khalifa''' ({{lang-ar|محمد جمال خليفه}}) (1 February 1957 – 31 January 2007) was a [[Saudi]] businessman from [[Jeddah]] who married one of [[Osama bin Laden]]'s sisters.<ref name=CNNdead>{{cite news|title=Bin Laden's brother-in-law killed|publisher=CNN|date=31 January 2007|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/01/31/khalifa.death/index.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202030010/http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/meast/01/31/khalifa.death/index.html|archivedate=2 February 2007}}</ref> He has been accused of funding terror plots and groups in the [[Philippines]] in the 1990s while head of the [[International Islamic Relief Organization]] branch there.<ref name=abuza/><ref name=Gunaratna-182/> He was murdered in [[Madagascar]] in 2007.
==Biography== Khalifa is said to have trained with Osama Bin Laden in the [[mujahideen]] camps in [[Afghanistan]] during the [[Soviet–Afghan War]].<ref name="Fielding" />
===Philippines=== Khalifa came to the Philippines in 1987 or 1988. He was the first head of the [[International Islamic Relief Organization]]’s Philippine branch, and also the IIRO's regional director for all of Southeast Asia.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Commission on Terrorist Attacks upon the United States|url=http://govinfo.library.unt.edu/911/archive/hearing3/9-11Commission_Hearing_2003-07-09.htm|accessdate=19 June 2012|date=9 July 2003|quote=MR. GUNARATNA: Sir, Mohammad Jamal Khalifa ... arrived in the Philippines in 1988 and he became the first director, the founding director, of the International Islamic Relief Organization of Saudi Arabia.}}</ref><ref name=TFSR-120>{{cite book|last1=Giraldo|first1=Jeanne K.|last2=Trinkunas|first2=Harold A.|title=Terrorism Financing and State Responses: A Comparative Perspective|publisher=Sanford University Press|page=120 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BOfC7vJOsdIC&pg=PA120&lpg=PA120&dq=Mohammed+Jamal+Khalifa+iiro&source=bl&ots=E8bJaMnemX&sig=DGM389UfM0yHE9euElVA8XrFysc&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-QJUVeeqEM3YoASYt4CQBQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Mohammed%20Jamal%20Khalifa%20iiro&f=false|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=HC-MJK>{{cite web|title=Complete 911 Timeline. Mohammed Jamal Khalifa|url=http://www.historycommons.org/timeline.jsp?other_al-qaeda_operatives=complete_911_timeline_mohammed_jamal_khalifa&timeline=complete_911_timeline|website=History Commons|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref>
Khalifa had married a local woman, Alice "Jameelah" Yabo,<ref>{{cite book|last=Abuza|first=Zachary|title=Balik-Terrorism: The Return of the Abu Sayyaf|publisher=Strategic Studies Institute, US Army War College|location=Carlisle, Pennsylvania|isbn=1-58487-208-X|url=http://www.strategicstudiesinstitute.army.mil/pdffiles/pub625.pdf|page=47|date=September 2005|accessdate=19 June 2012|quote=Based on IIRO documents at the PSEC, Khalifa was one of five incorporators who signed the documents of registration; another was Khalifa's wife, Alice 'Jameelah' Yabo.}}</ref> and frequently exited and entered the country for "business" reasons. Yabo was the sister of Ahmad al-Hamwi, better known as Abu Omar.<ref> {{cite news|title=AFP was aware of 'al-Qaeda associate'|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/afp-was-aware-of-alqaeda-associate/2006/04/08/1143916754689.html|accessdate=20 June 2012|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=8 April 2006}}</ref>
According to Zachary Abuza writing in 2003, Khalifa established several charities and Islamic organizations in the Philippines ostensibly for charity and religious world but which channeled money to extremist groups.<ref name=abuza /> According to ''[[Newsweek]]'', Filipino officials suspect Khalifa may have raised as much as several hundred thousand dollars during his eight years in the Philippines, but most of the money (as much as 70 percent, according to Wahab Akbar, governor of the Basilan region where the [[Abu Sayyaf]] is based) was spent funding Islamic extremists like Abu Sayyaf.<ref name=Newsweek-21-10-01>{{cite news|title=Taking From The Poor|url=http://www.newsweek.com/taking-poor-154043|accessdate=15 May 2015|work=Newsweek|date=21 October 2001}}</ref> One example of his syphoning off of charitable funds, according to Newsweek, was his reporting to his "Saudi sponsors" that he had built 33 orphanages across the southern Philippines with "the funds they had sent him", when in fact Khalifa had set up only one institution for orphans.<ref name=Newsweek-21-10-01/>
Khalifa founded the "Benevolence International Corporation" (BIC) in the Philippines in 1988, apparently to recruit people for the Afghan jihad against the Soviets. The BIC claimed to be an import-export company. In 1992, that group folded visible operations while another group known as the Islamic Benevolence Committee renamed itself to [[Benevolence International Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Treasury designates Benevolence International Foundation and related entities as financiers of terrorism|url=http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/po3632.aspx|publisher=US Department of the Treasury|accessdate=19 June 2012|date=19 November 2002}}</ref> What was left of the Benevolence International Corporation allegedly gave logistical support to terrorists,<ref>{{cite web|author=[[George W. Bush]]|title=Executive Order 13224 blocking Terrorist Property and a summary of the Terrorism Sanctions Regulations|url=http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/terror.pdf|date=23 September 2001|accessdate=19 June 2012|location=Names of entities designated on 19 November 2002|page=5|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130228090201/http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/terror.pdf|archivedate=28 February 2013}}</ref> and has been accused of assisting the 1993 [[World Trade Center bombing]] and the [[Bojinka plot]] (of [[Khalid Sheikh Mohammed]], [[Ramzi Yousef]] to blow up 11 American jetliners killing 4,000 people in early 1995).<ref name=abuza />
Another organization founded by Khalifa, the International Relations and Information Center, has been called (by Zachary Abuza) the "primary funding mechanism" for the [[Bojinka plot|Bojinka plan]]. Money was embezzled from the International Relations and Information Center through the bank account of Omar Abu Omar,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Abuza|first=Zachary |title=Funding Terrorism in Southeast Asia: The Financial Network of Al Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah|journal=NBR Analysis|date=December 2003|volume=14|issue=5|page=27 }}</ref> an employee at the center, to an account under the name of Adel Sabah, an alias of Ramzi Yousef.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ramzi Yousef|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/security/profiles/ramzi_yousef.htm|publisher=Global Security.org|accessdate=19 June 2012}}</ref>
According to the Philippines National Security Advisor, Roilo Golez, Khalifa "built up the good will of the community through charity and then turned segments of the population into agents."<ref name=abuza /> A Philippines intelligence report claimed that "the IIRO which claims to be a relief institution is being utilized by foreign extremist as a pipeline through which funding for the local extremists are being coursed through".<ref name=abuza />
A defector from the [[Abu Sayyaf]] Group (ASG) told authorities "The IIRO was behind the construction of Mosques, school buildings and other livelihood projects" but only "in areas penetrated, highly influenced and controlled by the Abu Sayyaf." According to the defector "Only 10 to 30% of the foreign funding goes to the legitimate relief and livelihood projects and the rest go to terrorist operations."<ref name=abuza />
According to [[Rohan Gunaratna]], Khalifa dispatched at least one Filipino youth to Tripoli, Libya, on an eight-month training course and on his return in 1990 urged him to join ASG.<ref name=abuza /> He sent other ASG members for religious training to the [[International Islamic University, Islamabad|International Islamic University]] in Pakistan and for military training with Al Qaeda's International Islamic Brigade in Afghanistan, their visits being financed by IIRO.<ref name=abuza />
From the Philippines, he "established links with Islamists in Iraq, Jordan, Turkey, Russia, Malaysia, the UAE, Romania, Lebanon, Syria, Pakistan, Albania, the Netherlands and Morocco, enabling the ASG to develop relationships with terrorist groups" throughout the Middle East and Asia.<ref name=Gunaratna-182>{{cite book|last1=Gunaratna|first1=Rohan|title=Inside Al Qaeda: Global Network of Terror|date=2002|publisher=Columbia University Press|pages=182–83|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rO2HY8unF_sC&pg=PA182&dq=International+Relations+and+Information+Center+Benevolence+International+Corporation&hl=en&sa=X&ei=t8NUVa_4B4jGogTyiIHwCA&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=International%20Relations%20and%20Information%20Center%20Benevolence%20International%20Corporation&f=false|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref>
According to Abuza, while Philippine government claimed to have shut down all the charities run by Khalifa to finance Abu Sayyaf, a senior Philippine intelligence official complained to him, "We could not touch the IIRO" because "intense diplomatic pressure" from Saudi Arabia kept the charity open. "Their most important source of leverage was the visas and jobs for several hundred thousand Filipino guest workers", which they could withhold if the Philippine government angered them.<ref name=abuza>Zachary Abuza, “[https://www.jstor.org/stable/25798639 Funding Terrorism in Southeast Asia: The Financial Network of Al Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah]”, ''The National Bureau of Asian Research'' 14, no. 5 (December 2003), pg. 176.</ref>
===Deportation and release=== The first record U.S. authorities had of Khalifa reportedly came in 1992, when his alias "Barra" appeared on a bomb-making manual carried by Ahmed Ajaj who entered the United States on a false passport.<ref name=forest-73>{{cite book|last1=Forest|first1=James J. F.|title=Countering Terrorism and Insurgency in the 21st Century: Lessons from the ...|date=2007|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|page=73|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MDXWDJocZBgC&pg=PA73&dq=Ahmed+Ajaj+Mohammed+Jamal+Khalifa&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YMFUVevCH9CloQTbyYHYCg&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Ahmed%20Ajaj%20Mohammed%20Jamal%20Khalifa&f=false|accessdate=13 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Berger|first=JM|title=The Unfinished Investigation|url=http://intelwire.egoplex.com/okc-overview.html|publisher=INTELWIRE.com|accessdate=19 June 2012|date=December 2004|quote=An alias used by Khalifa, Abu Barra, was written inside the cover of one of Ahmed Ajaj's bomb manuals.}}</ref>
On 1 December 1994, Khalifa met [[Mohamed Loay Bayazid]], the president of Benevolence International Foundation, in the [[United States]]. Khalifa and Bayazid were arrested on December 14, 1994, in [[Mountain View, Santa Clara County, California|Mountain View, California]] on charges related to the [[1993 World Trade Center bombing]]. Khalifa was planning to fly to the Philippines.<ref name="Rizzo">{{cite news|last=Rizzo|first=Tony|title=KC man linked to early al-Qaida|newspaper=The Kansas City Star|date=9 September 2006|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/org/news/2006/060909-alqaeda-link.htm|accessdate=19 June 2012}}</ref>
When the [[FBI]] looked inside Khalifa's luggage, they found manuals in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] on training terrorists, which covered subjects such as bomb-making and other violent activities. Khalifa claims that his possession of the materials was innocent. They found a personal organizer with several contacts. One phone number was for [[Wali Khan Amin Shah]], a member of the [[Manila]] cell, which was plotting [[Operation Bojinka]] at the time. There was also a listing for an unknown man, who might have been [[Khalid Sheik Mohammed]]. Khalifa was placed in solitary confinement and the contents of his luggage were logged and edited.<ref name="Bonner-Weiser">{{cite news|title=Echoes of early design to use chemicals to blow up airliners|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/11/world/europe/11manila.html?_r=1&ref=bojinkajetlinersbombplot|accessdate=20 June 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=11 August 2006|author=Raymond Bonner|author2=Benjamin Weiser}}</ref>
Khalifa was held without bail for several months, before being deported to Jordan.<ref name=Abuza-108>{{cite book|last1=Abuza|first1=Zachary|title=Militant Islam in Southeast Asia: Crucible of Terror|publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers.|date=2003|page=108|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QqgiE94IAmIC&pg=PA108&dq=Mohammed+Jamal+Khalifa+deported+united+states&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gm9XVe2uGYWOyASBwoCgBQ&ved=0CFMQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Mohammed%20Jamal%20Khalifa%20deported%20united%20states&f=false|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Gunaratna-182/> In [[Jordan]], a court had convicted Khalifa in absentia for a string of theatre bombings. Khalifa faced a possible [[death sentence]] as a result. Khalifa first fought his deportation by suing the government.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}}
On 6-7 January 1995, Operation Bojinka was discovered after a fire at [[Ramzi Yousef]]'s [[Manila]] apartment. Investigators found evidence related to the plot.<ref name="Bonner-Weiser"/> [[Abdul Hakim Murad (militant)|Abdul Hakim Murad]], who was arrested at the apartment, had five phone numbers pointing to Khalifa. They also found logs of phone calls to and from Khalifa before his arrest and contact information on Yousef's computer.{{Citation needed|date=June 2012}}
Despite this evidence, forwarded to the United States from the Philippines in March 1995, suggesting Khalifa was funding the foiled Operation Bojinka plot, Khalifa was not arrested but his belongs were returned and he was deported to Jordan on May 5 by the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service|INS]] as he requested. (Despite the fact that on 18 April, the conviction in Jordan was overturned as a key witness recanted his testimony.) In Jordan, a court acquitted Khalifa. Bayazid was also let go. Khalifa left for the Philippines and returned to Saudi Arabia.<ref name=Gunaratna-182/> The US deported him to Lebanon where he had already been sentenced to death in absentia for conspiracy to carry out terrorist acts. He was re-tried and acquitted, then released to Saudi Arabia.<ref name=Abuza-108/>
Khalifa was arrested in Saudi Arabia shortly after the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]] attacks, but was released without charges being filed. Later that year, he publicly condemned Osama Bin Laden and publicly distanced himself from Al Qaeda.<ref name="Fielding">{{cite news|last=Fielding|first=Nick|title=Gems, al-Qaida and murder. Mystery over killing of Osama Bin Laden's friend|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/mar/02/alqaida.saudiarabia|accessdate=19 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=1 March 2007}}</ref>
===Death=== On 31 January 2007, the day before his 50th birthday, Khalifa was killed while visiting a gemstone mine he owned in Sakamilko, near the town of [[Sakaraha]] in southern [[Madagascar]]. Reports state that around 25 to 30 armed men raided Khalifa's residence in the middle of the night, attacked him with various weapons, and removed his computer and other intelligence materials. His family came to believe that he was assassinated by operators from the [[Joint Special Operations Command]].<ref name="Fielding"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Mohammed Jamal Khalifa, Osama bin Laden's brother-in-law, killed in Madagascar|url=http://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2007/01/mohammed_jamal_khali.php|accessdate=19 June 2012|newspaper=longwarjournal|date=31 January 2007|author=Reuters|author2=Sami Aboudi|author3=Bill Roggio}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Portal|Saudi Arabia|Biography|Terrorism}} * [http://topics.nytimes.com/topics/reference/timestopics/subjects/t/terrorism/bojinka_jetliners_bomb_plot/index.html Bojinka jetliners bomb plot navigator] ''New York Times'' summary of its articles about Bojinka.

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Mafijaska pudla | native_name = Небојша Човић | native_name_lang = sr | image = Nebojša Čović Cropped.jpg | image_size = | caption = {{small|Čović at an [[Social Democratic Party (Serbia 2001–2010)|SDP]] press conference in June 2006.}} | order = [[Government of Serbia (2001–2004)|Deputy Prime Minister of Serbia]] | primeminister = [[Zoran Đinđić]]
[[Zoran Živković (politician)|Zoran Živković]] | term_start = 25 January 2001 | term_end = 3 March 2004 | predecessor = [[Spasoje Krunić]] | successor = [[Miroljub Labus]] | order1 = [[Government of Serbia (2001–2004)|Prime Minister of Serbia]]
Acting | term_start1 = 12 March 2003 | term_end1 = 16 March 2003 | order2 = 66th [[Mayor of Belgrade]] | term_start2 = 23 June 1994 | term_end2 = 21 February 1997 | predecessor2 = [[Slobodanka Gruden]] | successor2 = [[Zoran Đinđić]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1958|7|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Belgrade]], [[People's Republic of Serbia|PR Serbia]], [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|FPR Yugoslavia]] | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = | alma_mater = [[University of Belgrade]] | nationality = Serbian | occupation = Politician, businessman | profession = Mechanical engineer | party = [[Socialist Party of Serbia]] {{small|(1990–1997)}}
[[Democratic Alternative (Serbia)|Democratic Alternative]] {{small|(1997–2004)}}
[[Social Democratic Party (Serbia 2001-2010)|Social Democratic Party]] {{small|(2004–2010)}} }} '''Nebojša Čović''' ({{lang-sr-Cyrl|Небојша Човић}}; born 2 July 1958) is a Serbian businessman and basketball executive and former politician. He currently serves as a president for the [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena zvezda]]. ==Early years and education== Čović was born in [[Belgrade]], [[People's Republic of Serbia|PR Serbia]], [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia|FPR Yugoslavia]], and graduated from the [[University of Belgrade]]'s Faculty of Mechanical Engineering. In 2000, he obtained his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D]] at the same university. ==Political career== In 1992, as a member of the [[Socialist Party of Serbia]] (SPS), 34-year-old Čović started his climb up the political ladder with a position of executive board vice-president in charge of economy and finances at the Belgrade city assembly. A year later, in 1993, he advanced to the position of the city government president. In 1994 he got elected as the [[Mayor of Belgrade]]. In parallel, Čović was the SPS [[deputy (legislator)|deputy]] ([[Member of Parliament|MP]]) in the [[National Assembly of Serbia|Serbian National Assembly]]. Čović was sacked from the mayoral post in mid January 1997 by the Serbian president and SPS party leader [[Slobodan Milošević]] amid the [[1996–1997 protests in Serbia|months-long protests]] in Serbia over the November 1996 municipal elections fraud.[http://articles.cnn.com/1997-01-14/world/9701_14_yugo.update_1_zajedno-vuk-draskovic-serbian-president-slobodan-milosevic?_s=PM:WORLD Milosevic sacks mayors of Belgrade and Nis], cnn.com, 14 January 1997. He was expelled from SPS on the same occasion. He became the president of [[Democratic Alternative (Serbia)|Democratic Alternative]] (DA) after the party got formed by certain number of SPS members seceded from SPS in July 1997.[http://www.ex-yupress.com/danas/danas7.html Nebojsa Covic, president of the Democratic Alternative and former mayor of Belgrade: Ms. Mira Markovic Annulled November 1996 Elections, EX-YU Press, 21 November 1998] Čović served as the head of the Coordination Center for Kosovo and Metohija and as the head of the Southern Serbia Coordination Center during [[Insurgency in the Preševo Valley|Preševo Valley conflict]] (1999–2001).[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/old_archive-article.php?yyyy=2004&mm=02&dd=26&nav_category=12&nav_id=27154 Covic to stay at Kosovo Coordination Centre], B92.net, 26 February 2004. From 24 October 2000 to 25 January 2001 he was a member of the trio Co-Prime Ministers together with [[Milomir Minić]] from SPS and [[Spasoje Krunić]] from the [[Serbian Renewal Movement]] (SPO) that transitionally governed Serbia after the [[Bulldozer Revolution]], when [[Mirko Marjanović]] was sacked. After the [[assassination of Zoran Đinđić]], he was the acting Prime Minister of Serbia from 12 to 16 March 2003.[http://articles.cnn.com/2003-03-12/world/serbia.djindjic.shooting.1235_1_prime-minister-djindjic-natasa-micic-zoran-djindjic?_s=PM:WORLD Serbian PM shot dead], CNN.com, 12 March 2003. In 2004, his party Democratic Alternative merged into the [[Social Democratic Party (Serbia 2001–10)|Social Democratic Party]] (SDP). In 2005, he became president of the Social Democratic Party. The party ceased to exist in 2010.[http://www.vesti.rs/Vesti/Nebojsa-Covic-za-Press-POVRATAK-U-POLITIKU.html Povratak u politiku (in Serbian)][http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Politika/Politichka-scena-bez-Liberala-Srbije-SDP-a-SLS-a.sr.html Politička scena bez Liberala Srbije, SDP-a i SLS-a]; accessed 17 April 2015. {{sr icon}} He has been charged for corruption in January 2016.http://www.blic.rs/vesti/hronika/optuznica-protiv-nebojse-covica-dostavljena-specijalnom-sudu/ljjjk93 ==Sports administration career== ;FMP Železnik (1991–2011) {{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2015}} In 1991 Čović became involved with Serbian basketball club KK ILR Železnik, a dormant sports collective for the workers of state-owned Ivo Lola Ribar metallurgical factory. Inactive since 1986, the club got revived by Čović under the auspices of his privately-owned metal products factory Fabrika metalnih proizvoda AD and renamed [[FMP Železnik]]. Under his guidance and ownership, the club grew into one of the top teams in Serbia and [[FR Yugoslavia]], developing a reputation for player development and quality work with younger categories. By 1993, the club got its own basketball facility — the 2,000-seat [[Železnik Hall]] that served as its home arena form then on. Climbing rapidly up the basketball pyramid in FR Yugoslavia, FMP began the 1994-95 season in the Second Federal League, winning promotion to the country's [[YUBA League|top basketball competition]] for the following 1995-96 season. In 1998, Čović brought former Yugoslav national team player [[Ratko Radovanović]] on board as the club's sporting director. Radovanović soon became synonymous with the emerging club, making player personnel decisions and running its day-to-day operations. Čović's son [[Filip Čović|Filip]] later played as [[point guard]] for the club. ;Yugoslav Basketball Federation (1995–1997) {{BLP unsourced section|date=April 2015}} In late 1995, while simultaneously performing the city of Belgrade mayoral job as well as Serbian National Assembly MP duties, Čović became president of the [[Basketball Federation of Serbia and Montenegro|Yugoslav Basketball Federation]] (KSJ), succeeding Veselin "Vesko" Barović in the job. In addition to Čović's political connections through SPS, the rapid success of his club FMP Železnik that was about to start competing in the country's top league that season after multiple promotions was the best possible recommendation for the job. At the time when Čović came on board to lead the federation, FR Yugoslavia national team led by [[Dušan Ivković|Duda Ivković]] were the reigning [[EuroBasket 1995|European champions]], having returned to international competition following a four-year exile due to the UN embargo. Ivković soon stepped down and his assistant [[Željko Obradović]] took over the national team head coaching job. The national team had a great run at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, reaching the final against the American Dream Team composed of NBA players. In early 1997, soon after Čović's fall from grace in SPS, he was removed from the KSJ job as well. ==See also== * [[Mayor of Belgrade]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{commons category|Nebojša Čović}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{Succession box | before = [[Slobodanka Gruden]] | title = [[Mayor of Belgrade]] | years = 1994 – 1997 | after = [[Zoran Đinđić]] }} {{s-sports}} {{Succession box | before = [[Vladislav Lučić]] | title = President of the [[KK Crvena zvezda]] | years = 2011 – present | after = Incumbent }} {{Succession box | before = [[Mladen Veber]] | title = President of the [[ABA League JTD]] | years = 2017 – present | after = Incumbent }} {{Succession box | before = [[Veselin Barović]] | title = President of the [[Basketball Federation of Serbia and Montenegro|Basketball Federation of Yugoslavia]] | years = 1995 – 1997 | after = [[Dragoslav Ražnatović]] }} {{end}} {{KK Crvena zvezda}} {{Adriatic League}} {{BGMayor}} {{Cabinet of Serbia (2001–04)}} {{SerbianPM}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Covic, Nebojsa}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Belgrade]] [[Category:Socialist Party of Serbia politicians]] [[Category:Democratic Alternative (Serbia) politicians]] [[Category:Social Democratic Party (Serbia 2001–10) politicians]] [[Category:KK Crvena Zvezda executives]] [[Category:Mayors of Belgrade]] [[Category:Serbian businesspeople]] [[Category:Serbian basketball executives and administrators]] [[Category:University of Belgrade Faculty of Mechanical Engineering alumni]]
